choices.text: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
Immediate emergency room thoracotomy should be done
Echocardiogram should be done to confirm pericardial blood
The entry wound should be sealed with an occlusive dressing

questions.text: A 40-years old man brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to the chest. On examination patient is found to be hemodynamically stable. The neck veins are engorged and the heart sounds are muffled. The following statements are true for this patient except: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is correct as the case scenario points towards the diagnosis of pericardial tamponade. Option C is correct as even though the clinical scenario points towards pericardial tamponade we need to do a echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis by looking at the blood in the pericardial cavity. Option D is correct we need to seal the entry wound with occlusive dressing in order to prevent the ascending infection. Option B is wrong as we do not perform an emergency room thoracotomy we do an emergency thoracotomy in the operation theatre.

questions.text: Sitaram a 40-years old man, met with an accident and comes to emergency department with engorged neck veins, rapid pulse and chest pain Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Raised JVP, engorged neck veins, hypotension and chest pain points towards cardiac tamponade. Option A that is pulmonary laceration presents as difficulty in respiration and fullness of the chest and due to this patient might develop hemothorax. Option D In splenic rupture patient presents with severe hypotension and distended abdomen due to hemoperitoneum.

questions.text: Treatment of flail chest with respiratory distress
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment of rib fracture is analgesia and if it is causing lung contusion with respiratory failure we have to subject the patient to intubation with IPPV ventilation.

questions.text: Best approach in thoracic trauma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Best approach for thoracic trauma is anterolateral thoracotomy as it can help us gain rapid access to the lungs and the site of injury.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in severe fail chest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Positive pressure ventilation is needed in severe fail chest injuries where patient has impending or eminent respiratory failure. In these patients positive pressure acts like a splint and maintains the respiration in such patients. Strapping is never a treatment option for any degree of flail chest, it infact deteriorates the condition if done. Wiring can be done in cases of severe flail chest which are not improving with IPPV Nasal oxygen is definitely needed in flail chest as a supportive, but the treatment of choice in severe flail chest is endotracheal intubation, IPPV and supplying oxygen via endotracheal tube .

questions.text: The immediate treatment of choice in most cases of flail chest is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most of the flail chests are not very severe and the main treatment required is analgesics to fight the intense pain of the broken ribs, if you provide adequate analgesia the person continues to breath adequately and does not land up into respiratory failure. Option B is not an immediate intervention which is required in most of the cases. Positive pressure ventilation is needed only in severe flail chest injuries where patient has impending or eminent respiratory failure. So positive pressure acts like a splint and maintains the respiration in such patients. Option C is never a treatment option for flail chest as problem is at the level of lungs and tracheostomy helps for problems of upper airway. Option D is not an immediate intervention. Breathing exercises do help in the course of recovery but they are never the mainstay of treatment for flail chest.

questions.text: Steering wheel injury on chest of a young man reveals multiple fractures of ribs and paradoxical movement with severe respiratory distress. X-ray shows pulmonary contusion on right side without pneumothorax. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Immediate Endotracheal intubation with positive pressure ventilation is needed in severe fail chest injuries where patient has impending or eminent respiratory failure. In these patients positive pressure acts like a splint and maintains the respiration in such patients. So in cases of severe flail chest IPPV is the treatment of choice. Internal fixation and stabilization of ribs using towel clips are also helpful in cases of severe flail chest but they are planned procedures and immediate treatment is always endotracheal intubation and positive pressure ventilation. Thoracic epidural anaesthesia and O2 therapy will not be helpful for severe flail chest with respiratory failure.

questions.text: True about flail chest are all except:(LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Flail chest is a condition in which there occurs 2 or more fractures in same rib in 2 or more consecutive ribs. Such pattern of fracture separates the fracture segment from rest of bony cage and with inspiration this segment tends to go in rather than coming out, this is called paradoxical respiration. If flail chest is left untreated and progresses or if it is severe to begin with it can lead to respiratory failure. Mediastinal shift is not a component of flail chest.

questions.text: Simple rib fracture should be treated with all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stapping of chest is never a treatment option for a rib fracture as it causes further restriction in the expansion of the chest and is infact detrimental rather than helping for the patients with rib fracture . Analgesics are the primary treatment therapy for the patients with rib fracture provided patients are not in respiratory failure. Physiotherapy and early ambulation are also beneficial for patients with rib fracture along the course of recovery as they promote proper lung ventilation.

choices.text: Left side rupture due to weak left hemidiaphragm at point of entry of embryonic origin
Smaller tears heal spontaneously and surgery is not required
Abdominal approach is the most favoured
Mask ventilation is encouraged in patient with massive visceral herniation

questions.text: Traumatic diaphragmatic injury except: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C & E) Remember if there is a traumatic diaphragmatic injury with a rent in the diaphragm, no matter how small the rent is it should be repaired surgically by using non absorbable sutures, if the rent is not repaired it will never heal spontaneously. Over a period of time the rent will increase in size and patient can present with a late complication as visceral herniation. Mask ventilation is contraindicated in case of traumatic diaphragmatic injury with visceral herniation because if patient is subjected to mask ventilation air can enter can enter the viscera and can further compromise ventilation of lungs. Option A is correct diaphragmatic rupture is more common on left side Option B is also correct most of the diaphragmatic ruptures are traumatic in nature and even in this penetrating abdominal injuries form a major chunk of all the injuries. Option D is correct whenever you have to repair a diaphragmatic rupture abdominal route is favoured because by this route we can also examine other intra abdominal organs for injury and we can have a proper exposure of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Diagnosis of traumatic rupture of diaphragm: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diagnosis of traumatic rupture of diaphragm can be best done by laparoscopy. So diagnostic laparoscopy is the investigation of choice. This also helps us to evaluate other intra abdominal organs and check for injury to any of these organs. X-ray can be useful in traumatic diagphragmatic injury only if there is massive visceral herniation into the thoracic cavity . Diagnostic peritoneal lavage can diagnose traumatic diaphragmatic injury if the wash fluid comes out from ICD, but sensitivity of this test is very poor. CT Scan can help us detect diaphragmatic injury if there is visceral herniation in the thoracic cavity. So out of all the above mentioned tests most sensitive investigation and investigation of choice to detect diaphragmatic injury is diagnostic laparoscopy.

questions.text: Due to decelerations, aorta can be ruptured at places where it is fixed except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The majority of blunt injuries to the thoracic aorta occur at aortic isthmus just distal to the left subclavian artery. Other locations include the transverse arch, proximal ascending aorta, and descending aorta just proximal to the diaphragm. • Tethering of aorta by the ligamentum arteriosum is believed to account for the high frequency of aortic injury in the isthmus region.

questions.text: During resuscitation, artefacts of fractured ribs most commonly involve: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) During resuscitation, artefacts of fractured ribs most commonly involve 3rd to 5th ribs.

questions.text: Diagnosis of traumatic rupture of diaphragm is made by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Best way to diagnose traumatic rupture of diaphragm is Laparoscopy. Option B. Chest X-ray can suggest about diaphragmatic rupture if there is herniation of some organs in the thoracic cavity. Option C. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage helps in finding or detecting intraperitoneal fluid collection. Option D. CT scan is not sensitive in detecting diaphragmatic rupture.

choices.text: Tendons should be repaired before nerves
Nerves should be repaired before tendons
Tendons should not be repaired at the same time

questions.text: During the surgical procedure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sequence of repair after injury: Bone Extensor tendons Flexor Tendons Arterial Anastomosis Nerves Venous Skin closure.

questions.text: A 20-years-old man is stabbed immediately to the left of the body of the sternum at the fifth intercostal space. The knife most likely penetrated the:
questions.solution: Correct answer (D) The right ventricle comprises most of the anterior surface of the heart.

questions.text: A patient with a left adrenal mass is scheduled for surgery. The surgeon is planning to approach the suprarenal area by removing the twelfth rib. With this approach, the surgeon should take particular care to avoid damaging which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The diaphragm is at particular risk because it is closely related to both the 12th rib and the suprarenal area. Surgeons sometimes call this the “perilous pleura” because of the care they must exercise with this approach. The close physical relationship also accounts for the pleural effusions seen in some patients with kidney infections. The other structures listed in the answers are not particularly vulnerable during the suggested surgical approach.

choices.text: Needle in 5th ICS followed by ICD placement.

questions.text: A male comes to emergency with RTA, Hypotension and dyspnea. Breath sound on right side is absent. CXR is shown above. What is the management of the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The given case scenario is of tension pneumothorax as patient is having dyspnea and hypotension with decreased breath sounds.On CXR:-collapsed right lung is seen by air in pleural cavity. Option A-Shift to OT for thoracotomy is not the 1st step. Option B-Close observation cannot be done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Option C-Put a needle in 5th ICS is the 1st step,but the best answer is D. Option D-Needle in 5th ICS followed by ICD placement is the best answer here.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His heart rate was 100/min, respiratory rate was 24/min. Chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is contraindicated in him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In this case, a 24-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident presents with an elevated heart rate and respiratory rate, which are signs of physiological stress, likely due to chest trauma. Although the chest X-ray is not shown here, trauma of this nature commonly results in injuries such as pneumothorax, rib fractures, or pulmonary contusions. In such patients, epidural anesthesia is contraindicated because it can worsen respiratory compromise by blocking the intercostal nerves needed for effective breathing. Additionally, epidural anesthesia causes vasodilation through sympathetic blockade, which may lead to hypotension — a serious risk in trauma patients who could already be experiencing blood loss or shock. Furthermore, if a spinal injury is suspected, inserting an epidural needle could cause further neurological damage. Therefore, in the context of this trauma scenario, epidural anesthesia is contraindicated

questions.text: X-ray is done in following cases of blunt trauma chest. In which of them, further investigations are required before inserting icd? 1. Flail chest 2. Pneumothorax 3. Diaphragmatic injury 4. Left sided pleural effusion/hemothorax.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 is Flail chest as ribs are fractured.Flail chest by itself is not an indication to put ICD. 2 is pneumothorax in which ICD should be put. 3 is diaphragmatic injury,in which ICD is contraindicated as it may cause injury to surrounding structures while inserting the tube. 4 is hemothorax in which ICD should be put.

questions.text: Not a Boundary of triangle of safety?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The triangle of safety is bordered by the pectoralis major anteriorly and latissimus dorsi posteriorly and the 5th intercostal space (roughly the level of the nipple in a thin male). The only muscles you need to go through to put ICD are the serratus anterior and intercostals. Posterior axillary line is not a boundary

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the left side of his chest. He is in acute distress, with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. On physical examination, there is decreased breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C-Pneumothorax is seen as areas of lucency with compressed lung margin. Option B-Hemothorax is seen as areas of radiopacity with reuslting compression of lung and pushing of mediastinum to opposite side. Option D-Lung contusion don't cause a homogeneous white opacity as seen here.

questions.text: CHEST TRAUMA WITH MULTIPLE RIB FRACTURE 3-8, FOR PAIN MANAGEMENT-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IN CASE OF CHEST TRAUMA WITH MULTIPLE RIB FRACTURE 3-8,THORACIC EPIDURAL BLOCK WILL BE GIVEN FOR PAIN MANAGEMENT AS IT WILL DECREASE PAIN SENSATIONS FROM THORACIC AREA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a stab wound to the chest. On examination, he has hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cardiac tamponade Beck’s Triad is a classic set of clinical findings associated with cardiac tamponade, which occurs due to the accumulation of fluid (often blood) in the pericardial sac, impairing cardiac filling. The three components are: 1. Hypotension: Due to reduced stroke volume and cardiac output. 2. Distended neck veins (jugular venous distension): Resulting from impaired venous return to the heart. 3. Muffled heart sounds: Due to fluid dampening the sound of heartbeats.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most sensitive for diagnosing cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Echocardiography Echocardiography is the most sensitive and specific investigation for cardiac tamponade. It reveals: • Pericardial effusion. • Diastolic collapse of the right atrium and/or ventricle (a hallmark of tamponade). Other investigations: • Chest X-ray: May show an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle heart") if effusion is large. • ECG: Shows low voltage QRS complexes or electrical alternans but is not as sensitive. • CT scan: Can detect pericardial fluid but is not typically the first-line test.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a blunt chest trauma. A bedside ultrasound is performed to evaluate for pneumothorax. Which of the following ultrasound findings is most indicative of a pneumothorax?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Barcode sign (stratosphere sign) on M-mode Key Ultrasound Findings for Pneumothorax: 1. Lung Sliding: o Represents the movement of the visceral pleura against the parietal pleura during respiration. o Absent lung sliding suggests a pneumothorax, as air in the pleural space disrupts the apposition of the pleurae. 2. M-mode Findings: o Seashore Sign: Normal finding indicating pleural apposition (seen in the absence of pneumothorax). o Barcode Sign (Stratosphere Sign): Pathological finding in pneumothorax. The pleural layers do not slide, resulting in a uniform pattern (like a barcode) on M-mode. 3. B-lines (Comet Tails): o Vertical, hyperechoic artifacts extending from the pleura to the depth of the screen. o Absence of B-lines may indicate pneumothorax, as air prevents their generation.

questions.text: In a patient with a suspected pneumothorax, which of the following ultrasound signs confirms the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lung point The lung point is a diagnostic ultrasound sign for pneumothorax. It represents the point where the normal lung sliding (intact pleura) transitions to an area of absent lung sliding (pneumothorax). Finding the lung point confirms the diagnosis and also indicates the size of the pneumothorax.
